page.title: 01INTRODUCTION TO FLAMBOROUGH
page.content: The chalk cliffs which curve from Sewerby to Flamborough Head are topped by a thin layer of boulder clay. They are naturally breached at Danes Dyke & South Landing, both of which are now nature trails. Flamborough, a former fishing village, is situated 2 miles inland from the eastern tip of the promontary. It now depends mainly on tourism & farming, nearby Bridlington provides some employment. There are small guest houses but most accommoda- tion is residential & includes a council estate. Much of the population is made up of retired people. The village has a church, chapel, primary school & a few shops which cater for the immediate needs of locals and tourists. Sewerby has few residents, most of the housing being holiday accommodation. There are 2 churches, 2 shops, a private school & Sewerby Hall
